thread.title: Arsenal earmark Massimiliano Allegri and Thomas Tuchel
thread.title_full: Arsenal earmark Massimiliano Allegri and Thomas Tuchel | Daily Mail Online

author: Kieran Gill for MailOnline
title: Arsenal earmark Massimiliano Allegri and Thomas Tuchel
text:
Massimiliano Allegri and Thomas Tuchel are two top contenders to become Arsenal boss with club officials considering their options for life after Arsene Wenger.
It is unclear as to whether the Frenchman will call it a day after 20 years in charge of the north London club, with his contract expiring at the end of this season.
Juventus manager Allegri and Borussia Dortmund boss Tuchel have been earmarked as early candidates, with the mood around Arsenal having altered in recent weeks.
Tuchel and Allegri are both highly regarded and in charge of two European heavyweights
Arsene Wenger's tenure has divided Arsenal fans and many want him out of the club
Insiders insisted in January that they were not worried about Wenger leaving, though two successive losses saw their season take a turn for the worse.
There are now major doubts over whether their manager will put pen to paper on a new £8million-per-year deal, particularly after he refused to put minds at ease at Thursday's press conference.
Players and staff are in the dark over what will happen, Sportsmail can confirm, with the 67-year-old’s future in his own hands.
Wenger's future is in his own hands and Stan Kroenke wants the Frenchman to stay
Thomas Tuchel's Borussia Dortmund side have been performing below expectations this term
Neither Allegri nor Tuchel have been approached and Arsenal owner Stan Kroenke wants Wenger to stay, though the clock is ticking.
Arsenal were beaten by Watford at home then swept aside by Chelsea – all but condemning them to a chase for Champions League football rather than a race for the title.
Wenger is the longest serving manager currently in the league after 20 years at the club
Massimiliano Allegri has vast experience and previously managed AC Milan before Juventus
Wenger was expected to sign a two-year extension on his current contract but admitted he felt let down by his players after the loss to Chelsea.
It was something that will have a big effect on his future, with Wenger heavily basing his decision on whether he feels he can still get the best out of his squad.
Arsenal play Hull on Saturday and then have to go up against Bayern Munich away in their Champions League last-16 first leg. It is a huge week for the club and Wenger.
Wenger faces a critical week with voices calling for his departure growing ever louder
